snippet: Congressional hearings will include General Motors, which learned of ignition switch problems in 2004, and federal safety regulators, who received more than 260 complaints.
abstract: House Energy and Commerce subcommittee starts investigation into slow response by General Motors and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to complaints about faulty ignition switches that have been linked to 13 deaths; hearings will include GM and agency.

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and BILL VLASIC
byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald reported from Washington and Bill Vlasic from Detroit.

lead_paragraph: Congressional hearings will include General Motors, which learned of ignition switch problems in 2004, and federal safety regulators, who received more than 260 complaints.

headline.main: House to Investigate Slow Response to Fault in G.M. Vehicles
headline.print_headline: House to Investigate Slow Response to Flaw in G.M. Vehicles
